results.title: Village on the Yarra
results.creator_credit: Peter Bence, Rob McCubbin and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: State Historian, Dr. Bernard Barrett talks about early Melbourne, the first landing parties in the Melbourne areas and the events leading up to its establishment on the banks of the Yarra.

results.title: Victoria's first settlers
results.creator_credit: Lili Steiner and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: The state historian of Victoria Mr Bernard Barrett talks to Trevor Lunn about Victoria’s Aboriginal past, the first British visitors, sealers and whalers and the settlements at Portland and Melbourne.

results.title: Victorian education history. - No. 1.
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description:
Three programs which show different periods of school life in Victoria. “A Day at Ascot-Vale School no. 2608” is a silent film showing some of the daily activities at a primary school in the twenties. The second film is silent and untitled, but shows life at a primary school in the 40’s or 50’s. The third film is similarly untitled but is in colour and with sound. It shows different aspects of teaching in Victoria in the 50’s, with a substantial section on teacher training and country schools. “Each one is different” introduces the concept of child-centred education in Victorian schools.

NFSA description:

1. Portrays the outdoor life at a school in Melbourne in the 1920’s. Shows school dress, assembly, physical training organised dancing and games, Junior Red Cross activities, mothers club and school committee. #2. Shows the then new facilities for infant children at South West Brunswick Primary School. #3. A teacher recruitment film for the Victorian Education Dept. Describes the training of primary teachers. #4. Aims to show how individual differences in children can be catered for in a primary school physical education program. Describes the basic skills of gymnastics and the techniques of supporting, transferring and managing the body weight through different activities.

results.title: Theatre: getting your act together
results.brief_description: Presents a behind-the-scenes look at the theatre and the roles of the playwright, director, actor and theatre production staff. Designed to promote students’ interest in the theatre and to provide them with an insight into the workings of two professional theatre companies - The Melbourne Theatre Company and Sydney’s King O’Malley Theatre Company. The program is divided into five sections: 1 What is theatre? 2 The playwright in society. 3 In rehearsal. 4 The performance. 5 Theatre in society.

results.title: Leah; Water rats; Alison; Tracey
results.creator_credit: Sabina Baltrukomis and New South Wales. Dept. of Health
results.brief_description: A compilation tape consisting of four programmes designed to promote discussion in the area of human relations. 1. Leah. Concerns the feelings of an adolescent girl in regard to her alcoholic father who embarrasses her in front of her friends. 2. Water rats. Looks at the peer pressure exerted amongst a group of adolescents to conform to the group’s standards. 3. Alison. Looks at the problems of an adolescent girl who cannot adjust to her single father’s need to have adult female companionship. 4 Tracey. Considers the situation of an adolescent girl subjected to pressure by her domineering father to perform well academically.

results.title: The Australian image. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: C Hunniford, N. Hildyard and Ray Edmondson
results.brief_description: Stop Laughing This is Serious explores the comedy of our past. From “Dad ‘n’ Dave” to “Crocodile Dundee”, the distinct Australian humour is reviewed on film. “Hooray for the Radio” follows the development of the radio world through the unique Australian voice. “The Other Film Industry” explores the important role of the documentary in recording events and images as they were. “You gotta be kidding” is a delightful review of film and radio from a child’s eye. Watch for “Kid’s Stakes”, “Bush Christmas”, “Storm Boy” and others.

results.title: The Australian image. Pt. 3
results.creator_credit: C Hunniford, S. Issac, N. Hildyard and Ray Edmondson
results.brief_description: A collection a four documentaries on the development of the Australian film and sound industries. The first part, entitled “Wonders of the Age”, presents internationally acclaimed Australian inventions such as race-camera, Imax giant screen projector and CMI computer music systems. The second part, entitled “Shed a Silent Tear”, looks at the making, as well as the restoration, of Australian silent films. The third part, entitled “The One Eyed Monster”, looks at the growth of Australian television industries, the production of series, mini-series, variety shows, news and sports coverage’s, and the ways in which television affected Australian life. The last part, entitled “A Future for the Past” shows how images of Australians are reflected in films, and efforts to preserve films and sound recordings by the National Film and Sound Archive.
